column10:
EDIT: Feb, 2024

I STILL suck at this game but it's enjoyable.

Takes a bit to understand the fluidity of combat as it'll come off as clunky at first, once it settles in you'll be in for a good time.

There's a few downsides to this kind of combat and it's because it's a BR and has combat mechanics resembling that akin to a fighting game, the netcode is infuriating and may leave you in distraught. Ping plays a huge part in this game and if yours is over a certain threshold (100+) it becomes more of prediction than it is reaction since your actions won't correlate 1:1 with what affects the other players. 

It's a very difficult game, nothing wrong with that; Say you're not a fan of studying mechanics, then its likely preferable to enjoy it for what it is. Play when you're in the mood for the gameplay provided and don't dig too deep.

If you decide to invest, there's a lot of guides online that can teach you how to do the stuff you see high-end players performing. As I mentioned earlier this game is ping based, its also FPS based as some things are simply impossible at lower FPS (~200).

Overall rating I held on release was 8/10; Today I feel 5/10 simply because netcode. 
I'll come back to this after I find the time to grind to Asura.

First off, I love this game, Words cannot describe how much i Adore and Love this game, all the combos, movement and skills. its a love letter for competitive fighting games. But wile I will recommend this game to everyone for years upon years. I have to be honest. With 1000 hours so far i have experienced this game have Huge ping or tick rate issues. before it wasn't to bad to deal with from time to time. tho annoying I have found ways to deal with it and become even better from it.
for those who want to know i`ve been in astral 2 before and was stuck due to having too many matches where my average score was higher than the entire lobby giving me less points even if i fought in the castle, doing the challenge when it spawns and coming 3rd 2nd or 1st. no complaint on that.
But to continue my main point. 24 Entertainment needs to desperately fix the ping or tick rate issue. 2 days ago, i have been experiencing way more inconsistencies. as a matter a fact its so bad now i`ve become so afraid to engage in fights because i`m not sure what could cause me to lose the entire fight. for context. there are times i will hit someone who clearly should get hit stunned, ignore damage and normal attack me, i have clips that show them not even glow blue to avoid the stagger and i have been losing that way frequently recently, another issue is that way more of my combos at 20-45 ping will fail and i have to be making new combos that work on higher ping players. with the risk of having more inconsistent movement. all of this is just a small portion of what i`ve had to deal with wile trying to be really good at the game.
why is it that people who have higher ping have a higher advantage over lower ping players. this NEEDS to be addressed. i have reached my limit. this needs to be fixed. until this gets fixed i will not change my review. i`m just one person but i`m sure a lot of people who have this way worst than me. PLEASE fix this. its terrible.

lastly there are times where the game with lag out for no reason especially when you load into a match and its at 144fps but then drops to 12fps or lower when you look at a specific player or players. like what even is that. if i restart my game mid match all lag goes away. is there some memory issue with the game? how long is this going to keep happening. and its not my pc. i had a friend buy parts to make his new pc, experience the same issue and upon restarting the game is back t normal.

I will make a video about this showing all the issues with analysis to back up my points and i wont stop till they see these issues.

Naraka: Bladepoint is not just a game; it's an adventure filled with emotions and intensity that I've immersed myself in for a whopping 918 hours. This title stands out as a unique and innovative gaming experience, from its combat mechanics to its graphics, creating a distinct and captivating gaming journey.

First and foremost, the unique combat system of Naraka: Bladepoint is something I cannot overlook. The perfect blend of martial arts and traditional weaponry makes each battle intricate and highly strategic. The developers have crafted a tight team and opponent system, from precise strikes to ninja-like maneuvers.

The graphics in Naraka: Bladepoint are a true work of art. The expansive world with diverse landscapes, from towering mountains to ancient towns, is authentically and beautifully portrayed. The realistic play of light and shadows creates a vibrant and stunning canvas every time you step into the world of Naraka.

One of the most distinctive and noteworthy features of Naraka: Bladepoint compared to other games is the "Grapple Hook" system. It's not just a handy tool for movement but a crucial part of the strategy. Mastering the Grapple Hook can put opponents in challenging situations, leading to thrilling and dramatic action sequences.

While the game has its standout qualities, it's not without minor flaws. There are issues with balance in some characters and weapons, occasionally resulting in unfair situations in battles. However, the frequent updates from the development team help improve and fine-tune the gaming experience.

In summary, after 918 hours of play, I still find Naraka: Bladepoint engaging and passionate. The combination of a unique combat system, excellent graphics, and intense atmosphere creates a game worth playing and experiencing. Naraka: Bladepoint is not just a game; it's an adventure that immerses players in a beautiful and captivating martial arts world.
This game is the single best thing out there at the moment.

I love this game.

In general battle royal is a fun aspect for me, but having the abilities to fight with swords and different abilities is quite fun!

Is it hard to understand the game? no, took me maybe 10-15 minutes to understand fully what I am doing yet I HAD and still have fun playing, manage to get first place in two matches (did quick match, my guess some are bots? can't really tell, yet some are players for sure, you can see the skins and outfits and so on). 

However, and this is minor I guess, connection can be a problem sometimes so make sure you have a stable connection without something that can effect it (don't browse or download anything while playing), also I advice a good PC, because the game is still taking a lot. 

So overall ? I love it, graphics are great, sound is good, weapons and the whole system is fun, I guess some heros are overpower yet it make sense, almost every game has this issues (Call of Duty with stronger weapons, StarCraft and so on).

8/10.

THE SHORT VERSION:
1. The abilities, buffs and weapon attack types are way too confusing to be a casual game and the lack of skillbased elements in the game makes it way less skillbased.
2. Unpolished game graphics and server (lag) wise.
3. Too many claimable's to the point where it's confusing (basic gacha style interface which I don't support)

THE LONG VERSION:
I recommend it since it's free, BUT only if you don't take it too seriously. This game has an extremely cool concept and I love the art style of it, however it's sadly executed poorly.

It's as if the game is in beta because it's extremely unpolished. It's graphics isn't optimized well enough and a little laggy on the server side. There is also way too many "rewards" to claim to the point where I'm not sure what I should prioritize to level up etc before the next match, it's just too confusing.

And my biggest problem with the game so far is that it's competitive, that's fine nothing wrong with that. But if you are going to make a "competitive" game, I think it's important that RNG is minimized, but more importantly not having any indicators on what mistakes you did that led to your death, never teaches you how to actually improve. For example I died a couple of times where i thought I could parry an attack, however it did not work. I didn't get a single indicator nor learned why I couldn't block that attack from the tutorial. I still have no idea if it was a hitbox problem, just lag or something else. World of Warcraft has a simple solution to this where you die, you get a simple overview of how you died.

Best BR in the market.

They have unique old school Melee only combat system with swords, daggers, spears, etc. based upon chinese/asian mythology.

The game also does a bunch of collaborations with well-known people and other games that includes Bruce Lee, Nier, Fall Guys and many more.

The skill ceiling is high in this game so for those of you guys that like sekiro and like mechanically challenging games, this game is for you.

10/10 would recommend.

Despite it's flaws (being a chinese-dominated game), I can say with complete honesty that I love this game and believe it to be an extremely refreshing, engaging and overall fun experience compared to other battle royale games. The complexities of melee combos, hero variety, graphics, cinematics (seriously, they need to pay their cinematic team more) and the variety of ways to play make it so enjoyable even when solo. For anyone who is willing to take a couple losses to chinese players and looking for a game that isn't just about shooting someone before they shoot you in a split second, I HIGHLY recommend this game.

To start off, Naraka is one of, if not the best Battle Royal I have played. From its precise timing needed for counters to overall gameplay, it is fun. I love the intricacy of the skins and map as it is immaculate. I have played this game for multiple years and always end up coming back to play. There are some problems though, mainly targeting the in-game purchases. 

In battle royales that I have played across the many years, NARAKA by far has the most expensive in-game purchases. You are guaranteed an "Exclusive Item" after opening 100 chests in the Treasure Pavilion, which costs up to 184 USD (pretty insane just to obtain 1 skin or weapon skin with cool animation VE that you don't even have to option to choose which one!). This is just absurd as someone who is a student and plays this game wanting some cool cosmetic items from time to time. Plus, you are not even guaranteed a Legendary item after 10 boxes, it just resets this 10 box recurrent mechanism after receiving an epic item. So, you could just receive all epic items and not a single legendary after opening 50 boxes. Realistically, If you want to get a skin from the loot box system I suggest not to and to buy a bundle. Even Gatcha games which have immense effects on gameplay with a P2W system have cheaper bundles and prices. And if you do not spend any money in this game, it is still viable to receive an "Exclusive Item", but only within the Lotus or Immortal Treasures. And keep in mind that the threshold for opening boxes until obtaining an "Exclusive Item" is 100, and after this 100 it is not a recurrent mechanism. So, you can open 100 more boxes and receive nothing. This mechanism does say there still is a chance at receiving an "Exclusive Item" before opening 100 but have only seen this happen very few amount of times (the chance is 0.3% but I do not believe that). And as someone who indulges in these amazing skins and weapon skins, it is difficult to keep on playing if these items are just nearly impossible to obtain. At that point, it is just window shopping. 

(And just want to state, that I love this game and the gameplay is on a whole other level. But the Purchases are not...)

I know that In-Game purchases are optional and you may be asking, "Then don't purchase anything if you are annoyed about the Treasure system". Well, Womp Womp; I still am going to. But it would be nice if NARAKA could maybe think about their player base (mostly young adults) and make a treasure system that favors those who play this game on a day-to-day or week-to-week basis. This game is a Chinese game so I have no idea about the market as far as in-game purchases for Chinese administrated games. But having a CHANCE, yes a CHANCE to obtain an exclusive skin that you can't even pick after 100 boxes later is ridiculous. Please at least take this post into consideration as I am sure half the player base feels the same. 

Thoughts from other players on reddit:

"Yeah, I personally never got anything pass purple rarity levels from the free lootboxes they gave me. I've been playing for atleast 10 moths. I hate lootboxes in general, but this game and the way it "treated" my free lootboxes was a dead giveaway never to spend. It's a shame, I love one of the costumes from Ziping Yin (a ghostly tale one) but Id never buy for that, it's potentially too much and the odds are always against you." -Accomplishes-Big-219

"The design in skins in this game is very top tier. Like extremely high effort - not an excuse, but it makes sense why they‚Äôre so expensive. But yeah. I wouldn‚Äôt just throw money at the boxes. You‚Äôll never get what you want when money is on the line. I‚Äôd just buy direct outfits you actually like to get them guaranteed and just play the game a lot to get the free boxes they give out. Luckily rn it‚Äôs anniversary so they‚Äôre giving out a lot of stuff and even OLDER chests!" - Full-Composer-404

"Yeah, the prices are absurd and generally, people who play for a long time would tell you to just avoid loot boxes here altogether. That being said, it's all just cosmetics, you'll get some along the way from events and just by playing the game. You DON'T need to spend a single penny." - seraphimax

I don't often write reviews, but given the number of EU and NA players discussing server issues, I felt it was essential to share my thoughts on this game as a South East Asia (SEA) player.

First and foremost, I have to say that the gameplay is incredibly addictive. It might have something to do with my fondness for For Honor; however, I find Naraka to be even better and more accessible than For Honor. So, if you're a regular For Honor player, you'll likely breeze through this game. People often say that Naraka is easy to learn but hard to master, and I can confirm that if you can hold your own in For Honor, you can dominate in this game.

Now, let's talk about the graphics. To be honest, there isn't much to critique here. The graphics are pretty impressive, and the animations are smooth and satisfying, without any awkwardness.

However, the primary reason I'm writing this review is to address the server problems. Many reviews have highlighted issues with EU and NA servers, including complaints about cheaters and Chinese players seemingly causing problems. But from my experience in the SEA region, these issues don't hold true. In my 87 hours of playtime, I haven't encountered a single cheater. As for Chinese players, they play just like anyone else, and I've had competitive matches against them. They're not the gaming gods some portray them to be. Regarding matchmaking times, solo queues can take a while, but in trios, I've had match-ups in seconds, with the longest wait being just three minutes during peak times (with over 50,000 players online). In my opinion, it's unfair to condemn the game and lower its rating based solely on these issues. If I took that approach, I'd be writing negative reviews for many games that neglect the SEA region. However, I understand that developers may not consider all regions their target market.

In conclusion, would I recommend Naraka? Absolutely.
Would I recommend it to EU and NA players? I can't say for sure, as I haven't experienced their server issues myself. But, judging from the reviews, it's probably better to err on the side of caution and avoid buying it, I suppose.
Would I recommend it to SEA players? Without a doubt.

Great game, great idea and combat system, sadly very frustrating due to:
>Ping compensation mechanic being abused by players playing on servers they're not meant to (There are literally combos that you can only pull off on high ping due to air attacks pushing people farther/higher to give players with high ping more time to react)
>Infinite spammable combos
>Inconsistent parries, i can only guess dependent on ping
>Lots of bots, making it unsatisfying when you can easily tell whos a bot, and realise that about 70% of players you meet in ranked matches are bots (with such a big playerbase, why do the devs even feel the need for bots past low ranks??)

If you really study the game you can usually counter the ping abuse, infinite combos and parry problems, but even if i like studying how games work, why would i want to spend so much time on finding out the minuscule details of the game code instead of just playing the game to get better, especially when I can get a better and more fair experience from other games out there? You basically need to be on the skill level of the top hundred players to be able to consistently counter ping abuse. It's a shame because i really like the idea and love action melee combat but at this point if i want a fairer competetive experience i'd rather just play some FPS. And even if i wanted to just play casually, too many people abuse the game in unranked matches too.

Absolutely love this game, despite the incredible difficulty spike. Early in the leagues, things are fine, but you're usually fighting bots so it builds your confidence up (while also giving you time to acclimate to the game.) DO NOT LET THIS DECEIVE YOU.

Once you start getting into higher tier lobbies, you'll find that mechanics become key. Every second of a fight is crucial, and you need to be constantly aware of what you're doing. As some might say, think of it like a fighting game. Every weapon has it's own styles, its on combos. Every character has their own unique abilities that needs to be mastered, both to fight against and with. Synergy can be key in group fights.

Overall though, it's a fantastic game and I've loved every minute of my time with it. I'd love to see something in a similar vein but with western knights and the like, but I know that likely will never come. Regardless, it's an absolute blast. Check it out!
nice

Could be a fun game if it was an actual PVP game, unfortunately it's not. In the casual game modes 90%-100% of the looby is filled with bots, and I don't believe that's actually because of the supposedly low player count in western regions but due to an intentional matchmaking system putting you in bot lobbies. This would also explain why it only takes about 10 seconds queue time to get you into a match. The devs really think that playing against bots to get you "familiar" with the game is more fun than playing against real players on your own skill level. 

The weirdest part about it though is that the Naraka community seemingly supports this or doesn't care about it. If you mention this issue on any forum you'll get responses like "just play ranked at least to platinum to be matched with less bots" (note that you're still playing against mostly bots in plat too, in RANKED), or simply mentioning that you're not good enough to be matched with real players yet. Weird response considering there's most definitely other players who suck as much as me at the game who I'm good enough to fight against. And even if this wasn't the case I'd heavily prefer to get railed by a higher skilled player than fight against an actual bot in a PVP game, I bet that's the case for almost everyone.

Ultimately, this certainly did and will drive almost every new player in my region (EU) away from the game, even though the game itself could be really enjoyable.

Always searched for a game with complex smooth medieval combat like Dark Souls III, but without the hustle of finding an opponent and also with a much more open world maybe moba like features. If you search for the same [b]Naraka is the absolute answere for you![/b] The art design is absolutely stunning, the world is majestic, the chinese art style is on the point and the skins are insanely beatiful. Evenly balanced cool looking and not too revealing yet charming ones. The gameplay is incredibly smooth, the combat is up-most perfect, easy to learn hard to master with a bit of salty parry mechanism in the middle. There are character specific skills and ultimates as well to spice it up. The world and movements are extremely complex and detailed. Each and every match is exciting and fun, provides the old-school adrenaline you had in games back in the days. The developers are player oriented and even the achievements are fun and reasonable to get, which is an extremely rare treasure nowadays. And basically that's it, there is not really much to say about it, [b]this game is obliviously a must-to-try without any questions[/b] a masterpiece and perfect in the current state. Congrats and much love for the studio, please stay like this forever in the future updates, having a blast with my wife and friends! 10/10

Here are a list of positives and negatives that I considered before deciding not to recommend this game. I won't mention everything, so I don't bore you, so only the main considerations will be discussed.

[b] (Notes) [/b] 
[list]
    [*] NARAKA utilises a kernel-level anti-cheat, which can access a wider, deeper range of information in your system to detect cheats.

Stay with me, I will try and paraphrase what I have read as simple as I can...

NARAKA's anti-cheat system requires you to disable two settings, VBS and memory integrity, which is used to prevent malicious code from being inserted into tasks under protection. Hence disabling such settings may be dangerous...

I have little knowledge about technology, so the websites I used for this information are listed below:
~ https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/hardware-security/enable-virtualization-based-protection-of-code-integrity
~ https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/design/device-experiences/oem-vbs

I just thought I would mention this before moving on.
It is completely up to you as to whether you believe this is a negative or not.

    [*] NARAKA is client-based, meaning that what you see on your monitor will always look like you have 0 latency. This leads to no rubber banding for example, regardless how high your latency is.

    [*] There is no region lock, meaning you can freely join servers from all over the planet. 

Knowing this, many players, however mostly experienced players, find enjoyment in server hopping to hunt easier prey, like me. This has been the case in my experience with the South East Asia (SEA) server.
 
I am aware that some people do find pleasure in such challenges, so again, I would imagine  that this point is based on personal preference.
[/list]



[b] Positives [/b]
[list]
    [*] The combat in NARAKA is fun to a degree.

    [*] Moving around is enjoyable, like when using the grappling hook, climbing, and sliding.

    [*] The character/hero customisation is interesting, with the ability to use AI to sculpt faces.

    [*] Though many parts about NARAKA feel similar to other battle-royales, I believe it has it's own individuality.
[/list]

[b] Negatives [/b] 
[list]
    [*] The original price for NARAKA was $29.95 AUD and now, it is free. This reflects what this game is actually worth. I'm mostly just disappointed that I had to pay for this.

I imagine the developers don't struggle with finances due to the large amount of in-game micro-transactions.

   [*] The anti-cheat itself, as intrusive as it is, doesn't seem to be working as intended. Cheaters are abundant.  

    [*] There are no Oceania servers for people like myself who live in this seemingly uninhabited area of planet Earth.

Thus, my experiences have been based on the SEA server (140 ping).

This high ping leads me to parrying, which is an issue as NARAKA is client-based, which I mentioned earlier in notes.

In short, do not bother parrying if you either have a high latency to the server or if your enemy has high latency to you.

While it may seem well timed on your monitor, by the time the data arrives to the server (high ping), your parry wouldn't have worked on your enemy. 
So from your enemy's perspective, you did not parry at all and can be attacked as if you were open.

I hope this is understandable. 

I also don't see how adding another server for Oceania players would decrease profits in the long-term. Oh well.

    [*] Steam Charts are not always indicative of the amount of players you will play with or against in-game. 
Even while there are bots and server hopping players, unfortunately queue times are still unpleasantly long (SEA server experience).

    [*] NARAKA is well optimised, if you install the game on a solid-state drive (SSD), which the game recommends
 
Playing this game on a hard-drive is awful, from long freezes to many stutters. After playing through two or more sessions, the textures and models are cached I believe and the game will return to a semi-normal state. 

So I understand we are moving into a future without HDD's, though must it be essential to have a SSD to be playable? I think I am just in denial.

    [*] NARAKA enjoys advertising their cash cow, which are in-game micro-transactions, as they are littered throughout the menus.

    [*] Lastly, NARAKA, must have difficulties in getting attention from players, as every time you exit the game, their social media profiles are shown on screen.

Please have some restraint.
[/list]

I hope this stupidly long review can be helpful for someone interested in NARAKA or for someone finding a reason to move on to something else.

I see this is one of those games the community is trying to rally against even without playing it or looking into it in any depth, and so I'll spend some of my life writing my first steam review.

I like hard games, I like Asian aesthetic and historical culture [as well as folklore], and I like uniqueness.  This game checks all those boxes well, and I've seen the game grow in playability since it's early seasons; In fact, I don't think they even called them seasons at first.  It's not perfect, and my biggest gripe at first was that it was a game with an upfront cost as well as many micro-transaction options.  The game is now free to play, however, and you unlock legendary skins/items every now and again from just playing, as well as offering ways to unlock playable characters of your choice with in-game currency.

When mentioning this game in conversation, I've been met with disinterest because of it's lack of popularity as well as some off-hand racism.  I encourage all that are looking for a challenging and fun game to give it a try despite these stigmas.  I'm very glad I tried it out that first time.

Since this is an honest review, I'll mention cons as well.  I feel there's just a bit too much going on in the main menus as far as events, currencies, packages, skins, doo-dads, links, texts, ect.  I DO enjoy it to some extent, as it's a fun tribute to the Chinese culture to have festivals and events and cool little gifts; However, it's just a bit excessive of this function, to the point where I don't know what some things are because I simply want to get into a battle most of the time and not try to track down what kind of coins I just acquired randomly and what shop I can use them in.

Gameplay-wise, I have a great time.  There are some very good players in this game, and it's very important to try to pick apart what exactly they're doing better than you and try to use those skills for yourself; Which is akin to martial arts, and I think that's cool.  A high-skill ceiling for sure, BUT those that are scared of this shouldn't fear TOO much.  There is a bot mode with 3 difficulties that you can play solo or with your friends so that there is no chance of being whipped up and down by the 'Lord of the Lobby', as I've affectionately named the player you can see in the lobby before you spawn in that has a mastery rank that you can't even understand.  Piggy-backing off that point, when you play PVP, there will be bots in the mix, and you will feel great for defeating many of them; But when you meet the 'Lord of the Lobby' in that same game, your fate will likely be sealed before you realize it is he/she.  It makes you pay more attention, if anything; BUT the skill jump can be a bit of a shock when it happens.

Might I add, you can accomplish the in game quests/achievements in the bot modes.

Overall, this is one of my favorite games to play lately.  I'm a bit of a casual gamer, as you can see I don't have thousands of hours in this game, only a hundred or so; But I still find it challenging and fun.  For fans of the Dynasty Warriors series, it will feel homey but also much more polished and fluid.  If I may interject with a comparison here, there are many, many Dynasty Warriors games, and they've gathered quite a following over the years.  However, they have been much of the same game with improvements here and there on graphics, features, and playability.  This is a fresh take on a very similar concept of gameplay, polishing it up and also incorporating pvp and online co-op.  Dynasty Warriors holds a place in my heart from years and years ago, and I think looking at the two side by side grows my love of Naraka to and even higher state.

I won't give a number rating for this game or any other game, that's not my style.  Just know I like this game a lot and I think more people should give it a try.  
Thank you for reading my review, and may your journeys be full of wonder.

I am a 63 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 16 now. My son got this game immediately after release. By the end of the week he had 36 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife and daughter had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories. He just told me he loved me for the first time since he was 7. 
I haven't heard those words from anyone in over 9 years. Frankly... I was planning to well.... This game saved my life and my family.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]

- awesome idea and flair to the game
- combat is quite enjoyable
- graphics are nice
- free events
- it's fun



[h1]Cons:[/h1]
Sadly some of the combat mechanics are not that well implemented. Even though it is fun, it feels quite clunky and unresponsive at times.

- Bad netcode makes combat inconsistent, punishing you for things you can't change
- Parrying as a core mechanic of the game doesn't work consistently. Succesfully parrying depends on your ping and the enemy's
    --> the parry window doesn't start when the animation starts (on your screen you parried in time but the attack goes through)
   --> Even if you parry with perfect timing, if the enemy's ping is too high, it will not count as parried
- I personally dislike the amount of stagger the combat entails in this game. If you get hit in team games, say goodbye to your freedom of movement as you will be staggered to death.
- Bots in ranked queues up until gold elo and in deathmatch
- Sometimes buggy environment interaction
- Devs don't care too much about issues voiced:  
     . No adjustments made to trios (Eg.: You will be perma stunned in 3v1 by grapple hook spam and spear spam), this is simple to fix but there has been no change since beta   
     . Complaints in their discord about the inconsistency of parries and other issues are answered with 'get good'  
     . Infinite combos that kill you from 100 to 0 without you being able to do something have been in the game since release and haven't been addressed

The only thing sharper than the swords are the insults your opponents hurl at you. It's like a martial arts movie on steroids, with warriors flipping around like acrobatic maniacs. The graphics are so crisp; you can almost feel the wind in your hair as you get sliced and diced. It's a battle royale where the only thing royale is the beatdown you deliver. Dodging arrows, pulling off crazy combos, and praying you don't faceplant off a cliff ‚Äì it's like a kung fu comedy, and you're the star. Just remember, in Naraka, revenge is a dish best served with a side of epic takedowns.

Honestly, this game has good concepts, fun game play, superb graphics, and a less toxic community. For that reason, I would not mind spending thousands USD to open their treasure boxes system as a mean to support their game. This is just my personal principle, e.g., if some game developer provides good gaming experience plus you made a lot, like literally, then would not mind supporting the game with my money.

However, when it comes to their treasure boxes, it is extremely frustrating and utterly disappointing, it is very arbitrary and very likely to be considered as a ''dishonest/fraudulent scheme'' in most countries. 

I am writing this based on my own personal experience. Since November 2022 to date, I have spend no less than HK$80,000 and guess what, I could not even got all season 5's red skins (incl. Fu & Ji Lanterns'). 

Further, the gaming community is getting toxic since after they made this game free for play, you have idiots everywhere arranged by the system for you, throwing all your game wasting your time. 

Since the game has become free to play, more imbeciles appeared and ruin the game experience. The developer doesnt seem to care and did nothing much which is really upsetting and dumb. Simple job but maybe their salary too low, cant brainstorm something better. It doesnt take much to punish toxic players who afk, fucks around, or even throwing the match halfway through.

But hey, no, they just focus on creating new fraudulent schemes like orb restyles? which even you spent thousands and wont get anything good.

They label me as "esteemed guest" what some stupid low IQ reason. The point is, for fuck sake, I got nothing being "esteemed guest" in the game? no special item, icon, drop rate, or anything but low drop rate and restyle for me.

Imagine at times having purchasing 600-700 treasures boxes and got not even 1 single red item.

Imagine the only time you get 1 red skin after spending more than 1000+ USD plus and what you get is a duplicated red item (which automatically turned into a useless spectral silk). 

Again, I invested because I appreciate their efforts in maintaining the game and creating new attractive skins. But if it is such a dishonest fraudulent scheme or system, this really puts me off completely.

Therefore, if you are new, my suggestion is just play it for fun since its free, and don't bother investing or contributing to the game.

My hope is that more and more people will boycott them because of their retarded fraudulent system.

This game is an amazing new rendition of the commonly known battle royale genre. With melee combat being the main way to fight it is very different from normal battle royale games and offers a lot of potential for new combos to be developed and to have an extremely high skill ceiling. At first the game was a bit iffy on its character balancing and game optimization but they have made it clear to me that they do really care about the game and are always looking to the community for ways to improve. Just in the recent patch notes that will come out the day after this review, there will be much needed optimization and even if it does not perfectly fix the problem I am glad they are making the steps towards the right direction. Although it is hard for me to play the game so consistently because the skill ceiling is so high I do enjoy the competitive environment and playing casually with my friends. There is a lot of potential in this game and I think I can strongly recommend this game now as the base of the game is quite solid.

:EDIT:

so from my original time of righting this review I have clocked many more hours into this game recently. I decided to give it a try once more and I'm pleasantly surprised at how much fun I'm actually having with a battle Royale game. 

the combat, the aesthetic, characters, uniqueness of each character, the customization tool for the characters, the maps, the overall Gameplay loop, and by god the cosmetic outfits are incredible. this is obviously a free to play game so there is going to be lots of micro transactions, just like any other F2P battle royale. 

recently there has been a big increase in the player base, I haven't noticed any stability or network issues. when I played it first about a year ago, there were huge problems with network issues and rampant Chinese players de-syncing everywhere on NA servers...this seems to have chilled down. I'm able to sign up for matches and get into one within 3 minutes time every time I queue.

the one thing I do want to bring up is the bot mode, you can level everything up just by playing bots, you have 3 difficulties and  the higher difficulty AI doesn't suck. I feel like I actually learned how to properly use the mechanics in the game by playing bot mode for about 25-30 hours of game time. when I started playing with real people, the first couple times you play against other players it will fill in bots, you may think you are doing incredible but after 3-4 matches you will start getting your butt kicked by other players. that is when I went back and trained in bot mode and cultivated characters, leveled up runes, etc. I've now been playing against real players in Trio mode/duo after playing medium to hard bots and It seems to have made a significant difference in how I play and use the mechanics, I understand blocking, countering, charge up moves and characters abilities. I'm not "MLG" or crazy good by any means, but this is one of the few games I've played where bot mode can ACTUALLY help make you better at the game.

As a player who has experienced a significant issue with Naraka, I feel compelled to share my story to caution potential players about the game's customer service and account management practices.
My Steam account was compromised, leading to unauthorized use of my account across various games, including Naraka. This resulted in a ban due to activities I did not commit. The account was used from multiple IP addresses for hacking in games like PUBG and Naraka.
After regaining control of my account, I provided detailed evidence of the breach, including records of offsite logins and the account recovery process. This evidence was sufficient for other games to understand the situation and lift the bans. However, Naraka's response was starkly different.
Despite presenting the same comprehensive evidence, Naraka refused to lift the ban on my account, citing 'technical reasons'. Surprisingly, their customer service acknowledged the situation indirectly by suggesting I repurchase the game to transfer my account information, an unreasonable proposal given the circumstances.

Issues of Concern:
Inconsistency and Unreasonableness: The refusal to unblock my account, despite clear evidence and actions taken by other game operators, is both inconsistent and unreasonable.
Failure in Customer Service: The solution offered by Naraka's customer service demonstrates a disregard for consumer rights and a lack of empathy for players who have been victims of account breaches.
Lack of Support in Crisis: As a consumer, I felt let down by Naraka's inability to provide meaningful support or understanding in a situation where my account was compromised without my fault.

My experience with Naraka has been frustrating and disheartening. It raises serious concerns about the game's approach to customer service and account security issues. I hope my experience serves as a warning to potential players about the risks involved and the lack of supportive response you might face in similar situations.
Prospective players should be aware of these issues before investing time and money in Naraka. It's crucial that a game not only provides a good playing experience but also reliable and fair customer support, which, in my case, was severely lacking.

A competitive game with a steep learning curve. It's good for challenging and engaging combat with forgiving and rewarding system placed. When you do pull off combo chains the feeling of accomplishment is there. Although cosmetics are indeed a bit more on the expensive side events make up for it allowing cosmetic items to be given for free or at a discounted price. The competitive scene is very in-depth and the skill gap can be always expanded with room for improvement. Towards the beginning of the games first arrival the controls did feel clunky, however overtime as the game has matured the controls have never felt better with the advent of how good your wifi/Internet connection is to the local server. 

Overall a good PVP with decent balancing and overall really good skill gap.

Some additional pro's are it includes a great PVE and side game modes like death match and free for all.

Basically 90% of the people you play against are not from your region, but are players that abuse high ping advantage on NA or EU servers.
This has been a well-known issue ever since the game came out & even though it is rather easy to fix, they prefer to release shiny new skins instead of a long overdue region lock. It's just sad honestly, because a lot of NA and EU players stopped playing the game because of it, even though it is overall a great game with a lot of potential. I run this game with RTX 3090 Founders, 64GB RAM and i9-10900K and I must say, the optimization of this game is not the best. Personally, I can run it on Ultimate settings, but out of all the games I own it is one of very few, if not the only one that makes my CPU and GPU run a bit more toasty than it needs to be.
The game is overall beautiful and I really enjoy playing it, especially with friends. However, these are issues that you could expect to be fixed after more than a year of this games' initial release.
I will probably still continue to play the game, but there is days when it just gets too bad with the non-existant region lock, that you simply cannot enjoy the game as much. Therefore, especially for people who just want to start getting into the game, I cannot recommend the game in its current state.

The Battle Royale genre doesn't need to be introduced to anyone, and many people are probably already tired of these games. But I think Naraka shows that there is still something fresh to be had in the genre.

According to the description, it's a melee-based battle royale. Although there are ranged weapons, their use is very limited. So how can you create melee situations in a genre where players are running around on large maps? The game's answer is the grappling hook, which is the main tool of mobility. I think the implementation is very impressive, it allows you to aim almost freely, you can shoot at anything while jumping or running, pull yourself towards it, and your character will dynamically grab onto any object or building element, and then you can continue climbing, jumping or attacking. The locations also support this kind of verticality. Of course, we can also hook our opponents if someone wants to run away from us. For beginners, this is probably the biggest difficulty, learning how to escape, because you need to know that you cannot hook players who are in Focus.

This is an element of the combat system, which is based on a rock-paper-scissors system. There are basic attacks that don't hurt much, but you can combo with them. You can attack in Focus by holding down the attack button or as part of the moveset of certain weapons. These are highlighted in blue, they do more damage than the basic attacks, which bounce off of them. So if a basic attack and a Focus attack clash, the latter wins. The third element is the Parry, which can only be used to counter Focus attacks, but the latter can be cancelled, for example, by jumping or crouching, and if you manage to bait out your opponent's empty Parry, you can punish it with basic attacks.

These are just the basics, the tip of the iceberg. Thanks to the uniqueness of the different weapons, the variety of different movement and attack techniques and character skills (not to mention the macro play of BR) the skill ceiling of the game is sky high and can only be learned with a lot of experience and watching youtube videos, as unfortunately the in-game tutorials are not very detailed. This has been improved recently, but it can't replace experience. This may sound scary, but I can say that learning the most basic combos and movement tech is enough to have fun and, speaking from personal experience, sometimes even to win.

The gameplay is also influenced by your choice of character. Since anyone can use any weapon, the main difference between characters is their abilities. Everyone has three standard abilities that can be used relatively often, and three ultimate abilities. You can only bring one of each in a loadout. Of course, this is not the only difference between our heroes, as each of them is a unique character, with their own story, attitude and looks. Most of them are a collection of Chinese fantasy tropes, with a few Japanese-inspired characters (onmyo mage, samurai) thrown in. Their design is almost like from a gacha game, with everyone being extremely sexy and (optionally) underdressed, but they can also be made unique with a variety of costumes. I think these look very cool and spectacular, clearly the main attractions when it comes to cosmetics. There are also additional ways to customize your heroes, such as belt, head, and back ornaments, you can change the look of weapons, the lobby backgrounds and poses, and the faces can also be customised in great detail, so everyone can create their dream waifu or husbando, or some horrible freak, whichever is your thing.

Cosmetics, and with them the microtransactions are the game‚Äôs primary source of revenue, and the devs went all in on this. There are multiple currencies, premium battlepasses, time-limited events, multiple kinds of lootboxes, daily, weekly and seasonal tasks, FOMO at its maximum. Whatever monetization tricks you can think of, this game has it. The menus are also very complicated and resemble gacha games, with lots of sub-screens and notifications everywhere. While the game was sold for money, I would have easily chalked this up as a complaint, but now that it's free, I don‚Äôt really care, but I can understand this being annoying to people. You can pick up a lot of cosmetics just by playing for free and casually though, so you won‚Äôt stay Deault for long.

The main attraction of the game is the Battle Royale mode, which can be played solo, or as duos or trios, but there are also other game modes, such as Bloodbath, which is a kind of deathmatch, or Capture the Spirit Well, which is a 12v12 objective capturing game. What's also interesting is the Campaign, or story mode, which can be played solo or co-op. Here you have separate missions, each with its own little story, cutscenes, with different tasks, and bossfights. Of course, this is also designed for multiple replays, each mission must be completed on different difficulties with different characters to get all the rewards and reach the endgame. This game mode is currently only active on weekends, but it is expanded seasonally by the devs. I really liked it, both in gameplay and story. While the narrative is pretty basic, but it was nice to learn more about the lore and characters. Unfortunately, in my experience, matchmaking in this mode on lower difficulties takes a lot of time, as most of the players are already grinding in the endgame.

The number of players has long been a problem. The game is big in China, with lots of players and million dollar tournaments, but it hasn't really taken off here in the West. Because of the small number of players, most lobbies are filled with bots, so you only encoutner human players in the last few circles. Players with very different skill levels can also end up in the same lobby too, which is also not a great experience. This didn't really bother me as a casual player, but for someone who takes competitive gaming seriously, it was a big negative. This situation is likely to improve now thanks to the game being free, but it‚Äôs hard to predict how much. It's not easy to get into the game and therefore not beginner friendly, but it also has to overcome certain prejudices. For example, many people write it off just because it's Chinese and F2P, and I've also seen the Kernel-level anticheat branded as "spyware", and it has received its own review bombing on Steam. Still, I see many positive reviews too and I hope the game expands. 

I'm not a Battle Royale fan, and I'm not into competitive multiplayer games either, but I did put 100+ hours into Naraka. The great movement and combat system, cool characters and spectacular fights in an interesting eastern fantasy world, and a little bit of FOMO of course, always drew me back to the game, and I don't regret the time I spent with it. If you have an affinity for BR, or multiplayer games in general, I think you should give it a try, there aren't many games like it.

Horrible competitive / PVP experience from launch till now Feb. 27, 2022, EU servers predominately filled with Asian players (oft VPN abusers who lag a lot, even randoms in duo or trios are losing connection through the whole match in your team ... therefore your stuff doesn't even register on similar enemies / players against you), unbalanced skill gap, players from Bronze V that die like flies (cuz they don't even know what dodge or parry is) ... face in the same match Platinum and even higher ranked lagging Asian players against them! Very oft you'll die to an epileptic masturbation 3-4 hit kill no-life player that swallowed every possible YouTube tutorial on how to be epilepticly efficient with combos (especially keyboard+mouse vs controller) ... vs a silver guy that is trying to understand the game (a silver guy dies in 3 hits from a platinum or empyrean trio player on spawn as he gets highlighted on the map because the no-life activated a bounty quest = minus reputation points for the silver guy = depression = refund or removal of the game = player base cuts in half). In addition, bad performance and big fps drops with a 3080ti and a 5950x overclocked, on any graphical settings (currently using the lowest settings for competitive and it's still very bad) The Asian invasion into the EU has been an issue since the release ... but nothing has been done yet.

I just can't believe how they queue up empyrean ranked trio players against silver ranked in solo (I faced it a lot) ... yo! If the guy's rank is so high in trios, it's obvious that you should NOT queue him against anything lower than platinum, even if the empyrean's guy solo rank is bronze 999 ... where's the common sense!? Oh, let's queue him against bronze because he's bronze in solo, and we're just going to ignore the fact that he's fucking empyrean in trios!

All I see is more and more donations in the shape of very expensive skins and gambling. BUT, where are the quality of life improvements?

Very bothering cons up till this day:

- Begging to follow their social media, on every game exit ... why!? We got that you have Twitter, ok? We got it ... why EVERY day!?

- The store is in $ U.S. Dollars globally, no regional / local currencies ...

I don't know what to say, from the moment the trailer was released I really didn't hesitate to wait, its presence as a batterroyale game with a combat system comes out of the main concept which is a new creation with sword fighting, this is the point, variations with grappling hooks, and special The skills of each character with a refreshing medieval Chinese design can of course be customized according to your wishes, of course accompanied by a talent tree that helps balance physical movement abilities in fighting in our playstyle.

The mechanism of the weapon system, especially melee weapons with various swords, means that we have to be smart in positioning, dash right and left behind, and slide forward. Overall, the focus mechanic of this weapon is the same, but the skills of each weapon in this mechanic are very different, it depends on us as players, we have to know what weapon is appropriate to use in counter, attack or defend conditions because the grip of each sword weapon here feels very different. For close combat, mid and hi combat, we have to know the timing and feel it. This is really a very difficult battle and tends to be surprising if we are hit by an opponent's combo coming behind us or locked with his grappling. We also have to be able to be similar to him through the balance of the additional talent abilities, even though we don't know what attack point the damage will be to the opponent's body. Not only talking about swords, here there is also quite a variety of weapon ranges where the bullet drop is also quite difficult to shoot because the opponent's movements are very agile and are influenced by the environment on the map.
The point is in this game, if you want to be able to compete, start learning about each weapon, then soul jade to adjust the additional abilities or skills of the weapon, and don't forget to understand the character of the hero you use. Regarding the battle map, here it is the last number, but it can be the first number if you want to run and attack, attack by surprise, or run away to hide and then get your revenge again. The message here, don't be too careless when you look at all the cosmetic/skin variants on offer, starting from the heroes and the weapons themselves which are very tempting and pleasing to the eye, your wallet may run low because this is really beautiful to have.

Maybe this is a brief review of this game, I really love this game, and it really stuck with me because of the innovation. If you like it and want me to review it more fully, give it a thumbs up and help upvote the comment..

Naraka is a wildly unstable game; It freezes like nothing you've ever played - sometimes for up to around 8 seconds at a time. I've gotten multiple random disconnects when my internet connection to everything else on my PC was perfectly fine. Sometimes the game doesn't ever unfreeze and just crashes instead. Sometimes my internet browser will crash while playing Naraka and is unfixable to the point where I have to restart the entire machine. At least one of these problems is basically guaranteed if you alt tab for even a second during any loading screen. I can say with the upmost confidence that these issues have lost me at least 30 rounds, enough to make me lose count. Sometimes everything runs smoothly, but then you run into an opponent dealing with one of the aforementioned issues which ruins the experience anyways by either giving you an unsatisfying free kill, or by dying to a Chinese player on a VPN who is teleporting around the battlefield cause they have 500 ping.

These issues are frustrating for sure, but it's amplified tenfold because past all of these constant technical issues is a wildly fun and refreshing Battle Royale game.

When Naraka works, its one of the most enjoyable multiplayer experiences I've had in a long time. The melee combat is a much more engaging and exciting take on the BR formula than any other game in the genre I've seen. The rock-paper-scissors formula of basic attacking, focus attacking, or parrying is simple enough to understand and get the hang of while more advanced mechanics baked in like jump/crouch/dash canceling, weapon and character specific combos, and souljades that change the properties of your weapon's attacks give the battle system some much appreciated depth that keeps you playing more rounds and striving to become a better player. 

Gameplay is enhanced with 7 different characters each with unique, customizable abilities who are all unlocked for free at the beginning of the game - along with new characters confirmed by the devs to be released later for in-game currency. (Yoto Hime is only free for a limited time I think, so might not be free when you read this) With 5 different melee weapons each with their own unique strengths and weaknesses, there's a lot of mechanics to learn and utilize. Of course there are still a multitude of different ranged weapons to wield, each also with their own different properties, but you wont be winning any full on fights with just these ranged options. This is because of how fast and fluid the movement in the game is. With grapple hooks and fast vertical movement a la Assassin's Creed (and actually less frustrating than AC), there are plenty of ways to reposition and maneuver around a fight and find different angles of attack.

The game is surprisingly entirely skill based, with the only aspect not being totally level at first is the glyph system - which is reminiscent of old League runes. Unlike old League runes however, it's extremely easy it is to completely max out your glyphs in Naraka with currency earned from playing the game. 

When you want a break from the BR mode, want to practice new combos and tech, or just want to de-tilt from the constant connection issues that got you killed very first 3 ranked games in a row, you can't do much better than the Bloodbath mode. This deathmatch style game mode is more fast paced and low stakes than the classic BR modes; with 10 minutes to score as many points as possible by killing as many other players as you can with the entire game's arsenal available from the start. It's an enjoyable change of pace and I hope to see more unique game modes released in the future.

When it works, Naraka is one of the most enjoyable Battle Royale experiences you can get. It's up to the devs at this point to keep me playing for a lot longer by ironing out connection and stability issues, because if left unattended for long enough it could change the recommendation of this review.

EDIT: It's been just over 2 years since I originally wrote this review and the game has changed significantly. A ton of new heroes and weapons, a new map, some interesting crossovers, console releases, and a new f2p model which probably should have been the case on release given the inclusion of a cash shop. Putting a cash shop in a game that you already have to pay for to play is a very bold move. One that I think only a handful of much more massive and popular games could get away with ie. FFXIV/WoW, but certainly not a generic looking Chinese developed online game that still has a broken translation in parts 2 years out from release.

A few side notes that I forgot to write back in 2021 was that the glyph system is redundant and functionally only exists as a coin sink. I also dislike the level of customization the game allows for these non custom heroes players can choose from. It's bad for game clarity and [i] WOULD [/i] disenfranchise any interesting design elements present in the characters the developers have created if there was any to begin with. All of these heroes are boring to look at and have almost zero personality. 

Overall, I would say the connection issues have generally improved, but not enough to significantly alter my interest in the game. The freezing is gone and the game generally loads much faster than on release, but the constant latency present in every aspect of gameplay is still extremely noticeable and taxing to the general experience. This essentially perma-lag that seems to be built into the game, possibly even by design, is still my biggest gripe and ultimately the reason this is a game I might revisit a couple times a year rather than a staple title on the top of my recently played library.

(Also as an aside, the near weekly blog posts by the developers that are solely lists of all the players they have banned that week and putting them on blast is a fucking gigachad move and I am a huge fan.)

This is probably the first Battle Royale game that I've enjoyed.

Edit: Now that I have an additional ~100 hours into the game I felt it's time to update my review. The game left a strong first impression; a primarily melee based battle royale with good movement and still good range combat that felt balanced. That said, I've found my desire to keep playing has declined significantly, and I think it's largely due to the character abilities. The balancing there could still use work. Abilities on most characters feel either worthless or totally overpowered, there is very little in between. If there were game modes without the abilities I think that would be a good band-aid, but it's something that needs work.

Edit2: I've decided to come back and play a few games after taking a break for nearly 2 years. Now that the game is free to play, I do still think it's worth a try if you're interested (as is the case with all free games.) However, they still haven't seemed to improve anything in regards to the aforementioned balancing issues.

So, I initially got this game when you had to pay for it two years ago. I played for two hours, then never played again until recently. With getting back into it, it was easy to get into the flow of the game, get used to counters (use tutorials or fight your friends if you can make custom rooms, which I'll get to in a bit), and get the victory royale. 

It's a fun battle royale to wack people with staffs, swords, great swords, and dual blades. It's Monster Hunter but PvP, lacking monsters (you can do PvE) and Rise movement x10. If you're wondering where the Standard/Deluxe/Ultimate Editions are at since the free-to-play conversion, you can buy the upgrades in-game. Upgrading your game will give you more freedom than the F2P limitations also. For about 980 gold (about $9.86), you can play the Ranked mode at Account Level 20 instead of the 50 and create custom lobbies to play with friends. You can still join them as a F2P, but not create them. Buying characters do not have a limit also if you buy an edition.

Anyway, jump into the world of Naraka if you're tired of shooting stuff and just want to wack people. Here is my refer-a-friend code (invite code) after completing the tutorial also: chmpwqawyy

[h2]Short Game Description[/h2]
Naraka Bladepoint is a free-to-play action and adventure battle royale game where sixty players will try to survive until they are the last survivor standing. For that, you will fight against others throughout a wide map while using different weapons as martial arts together.
[list]
[*][h3]Positives[/h3]
Discussing the positives, first of all, the game is now completely free, so now you can play this game alone or with friends, with many different game modes to choose from, giving you many hours to do different things without investing any money in it. Secondly, the gameplay is well done; it has many different unique attacks with each weapon as counter mechanics and character abilities that make the game even more exciting, requiring you to use them more carefully. Thirdly, despite the game having microtransactions, you can achieve most things by playing and completing quests.
[*][h3]Negatives[/h3]
On the negative side, the most notorious problem is that the game takes too much time loading textures if they're not on SSD (it's stated in the game, so they warn you in that aspect). It is somewhat disappointing in comparison to other games that can do the same but faster. Besides that, if you purchased the game previously, the reward you get for purchasing the game was somewhat disappointing; they could've been more generous. Too, the game feels somewhat messy; it feels like they spammed pile loots throughout every spot, achieving, with that, a map with a wide amount of useless loot. The last problem I have found is that the interface has too much information on screen in some sections of the game, which feels a bit complex to understand and, at the same time, unnecessary, especially when you are looking to upgrade your characters.
[/list][h2][u]Conclusion[/u][/h2]
To sum up, Naraka Bladepoint is a good game that has good mechanics and makes the experience enjoyable as you learn, but the main problem is that the game feels somewhat overwhelmed by unnecessary interface elements that sometimes make the learning of the game difficult, and you need an SSD to play this game or you will suffer at the start of the game. The game is a 7.25/10.

4 Nov, 2021:
There are layers game that I just won't ever understand.

Gameplay: Difficult as nails to get the mechanics down, but so damn satisfying when you do. But even then, there's always someone who knows the mechanics much better than you and annihilate you. I'll never fully comprehend the mechanics.

Costs: The game costs money. Okay, fine. But then you see that the game also has Free-To-Play systems in place. Battlepass, cosmetics, unlockable characters, etc. Why does it cost to play but also have microtransaction in-game as well? I'll never understand

Matchmaking: As per above, the mechanics and learning curve wouldn't be a huge problem.... if I matchmaked with folks on my level. Instead, I get matchmaked with Chinese players who know how to cancel moves and pull off insane 1-shot combos.... The skill gap is very evident and I just don't understand how.

Enjoyment: Despite what's mentioned, the game is actually stupid fun. When you can string a combo yourself and read your enemy's attack before they can pull it off, it's madly satisfactory to down them. The character customization is also top notch, the same level as what you'd get from an RPG (Skyrim, Cyberpunk etc.). You can make your player look yourself if you really want that. It's just difficult to fully recommend this game at this present time as the enjoyment can quickly dwindle within minutes of playing.

1/10/2023
Ever since this game went FTP, everything started to make sense. I've actually been smashing this game out on PS5 and boy does it feel good to be back.

The fights - Intense, visceral, challenging but fair, and still ever so satisfying to pull off chained combos, better yet, learning how to stop one. 

The Cost - It doesn't cost anything anymore, it's free, with it's free to play micro-transactions still in place. It simply makes sense now.

Matchmaking - A little odd. It's like they certainly took in my criticism and fixed the issue by placing you into a bunch of bot lobbies at first, then eases you into the real fights with each game you play. It works, and i'm now matched with people at my player level, allowing me to learn and do better in the next game.

Enjoyment - Still same same as what I've mentioned. It's fun, lots of fun. Even up against bots, you will find yourself learning the game's mechanics before you get thrown into the deeper end, humbling you in the process. But with one small downfall - No Aussie servers, making me still match make with Asians that are 10x better than me, but that's also part of the experience at this point.

Overall: They have certainly optimised and improved the game like they said it would. Hats off to the devs for being so passionate about their product. It's definitely worth trying.

I've come back to this a few times and all they keep working on is the cosmetics. 

But here's my two cents.

Positives - 

Unique melee combat focused battle royal game with emphasis on high skill ceiling combat.

The game-play is awesome when it works. Makes you feel very rewarded when you make a good choice with attacks or abilities to best someone. 

Really good looking environments with some pretty cool location changes across two BR maps. Ton's or other types of match types too including PVE experience.

Bunch of characters with unique abilities you can combo with a ton of weapons to create some pretty cool combos.

Some cool cosmetics for those that care about that.

Full customisation of a characters face i.e you can make someone look like squidward.

Free to play.

Negatives -

Terrible net-code. This combined with server hoppers doesn't make for much fun. Skills / Attacks can get avoided just because of this which can cost you a game. Typically got people skipping frames and teleporting around because of this. You'd think the person local would get an advantage but it goes to the person connecting from the other side of the planet???

You can literally go too another server and infinite combo someone because of poor connection. (Btw you mention this on their discord and you just get admins / E24 reps ignoring it like its not a problem or saying anyone can do this on any ping / frame settings). 

Combine the above with frame rates this becomes a nightmare where there is no consistency of things connecting or not connecting. Some combos are impossible on certain frames (low frames causes the user to possibly miss key inputs, imagine this on a platform fighting game.)

Poorly optimised. It seems like regardless the spec of your PC your always going to get frame rate dips and inconsistencies.

E24 regard the combat as "rock paper scissors" i.e basic attacks, charged attacks and parry. If some of those don't line up as expected because of frames / net-code then it just becomes frustrating which is probably why the player base has tanked since release (but that's just a speculation). Which brings me to my next point... 

Some matches can be desolate i.e you don't play VS anyone apart from bots or you get sudden influxes of experienced players into games and can be super competitive. The player base (at least in EU) is not large enough to give an enjoyable progression curve for anyone new to the game. I'm not looking to be the best, but i'm also not looking to play vs try hard server hoppers who ping abuse in ranked.

Bad character design and balance. Literally all the characters look the same to cater for a certain stereo type / trope. Pretty much all the female designs are "Hi i'm obnoxious and think i'm better than everyone plus I have zero personality." The male characters are just bland save a few.

They can't help themselves to release a character that is not broken or imbalanced. But this is  typical for most games these days for marketing purposes. i.e this character has to be a success so we need to make sure people play it for whatever the reason is.

----

In conclusion -

By no means I want this game to fail. It is a cool concept and is really fun to play.

But the negatives far outweigh the positives at the moment and they haven't really taken any steps to fix them since release. 

Will I keep playing? Yes absolutely because it is a fun game, but then i'll just get frustrated again because of inconsistency and uninstall till I see new patch notes. 

Because of that I wouldn't go out of my way to recommend it to anyone.

-Lobbies filled with Smurfs

-Poor Optimization.

-Aggressive Monetization.

-Totally unbalanced.

-End-game tier weapons in early loots allow some few players to snowball to the end of the match.

-Non-responsive combat.

-A critically flawed combat system.

-Clunky control.

-After market changes to virtual goods, you never know if the product you just purchased will be the subject for a up coming censorship patch in the future. They will basically "re-design" the whole product to be in line with China's standards for games.

-The communication between the developers and players is next to non-exist, they simply won't listen to players, and will just do everything in "their way".

So please, don't waste your hard-earned money on this game.

IHello dear community,

the gameplay is great, the combat can be satisfying and yes, it is for sure fun to play, but still I do not recommend to play - why?

GREED - 24 Entertainment is one of the most expensive if it comes to extreme skins. I would compare this to like to a 5 Star in Genshin Impact or smth like that.

To get a Extreme Skin in Naraka if you hit pity you have to spent 250 bucks, but wait... there are 2 extreme skins in a treasure. This means you have a 50/50 chance to get the one you want, if you are unlucky, you will just throw 500 bucks to them and if you think that's it, oh hell no..... In the recent patches we did get Star Collection. 

Star Collections are very limited and even harder to get.

I have friends, they started arguing with me because of this. Yes no one is forced to buy them, but does this mean, we as a gaming community should allow everything? This implies any company out there. To make a comparison, I would compare this to like a 5 star in Genshin Impact. Gache Game, you have a banner and a pity, just the price is different. As we know a extreme skin will cost minimum 250 bucks, for 250 bucks, you could get 3 five stars in Genshin or 6 Bikinis in Lost Ark or even 25 Battlepasses in any game you want. 

Way more content, way more variety and most important for sure way better value for that much money!

I want to set a sign, actually WE should set a sign, because without us 24 Entertainment would be nothing. They need players, they need their money so they are what we want and as a Gamer, we should be able to say stop, this is too much. In the end, do whatever you want. I will never judge someone or like that, but I wish we could get positives changes.... This would be great for everyone of us. 

To make one thing clear, I never said it should be free gifted, it's just we need a limit.... 250 is humongous

- The matchmaking is bullsh*t, most of the time you will be matched with many people with higher skill than you, even in ranked match.
- Gameplay and combat tactics required highly response user inputs to make combos with very fast time frame but the game seem to be f*king lag, fps unstable while in combat. This can be deal with a decent PC.
- The server is unfair since people mostly come from china with low ping and can easily beat other people from other countries. You mostly will die whenever counter with a chinese team. In some cases you will die within 1-2s while don't know why.
- Gacha is optional. But if you want your waifus or any characters that you like look good, please prepare a lot of money. This game has too many miscellaneous items for gacha.

Been playing for a while. The cosmetics cost a bit but you can unlock a lot just by playing which is nice. I don't like the extreme cosmetics being locked the way they are but theres usually plenty to choose from for your characters once you have played a few seasons so you can just invest in getting the season passes. If you buy one season pass as well and don't spend the gold from it you usually have enough or close to enough to unlock the next season too which is nice.

Gameplay overall is fun if you like melee combat and generally I find it well balanced. Being able to play bot rounds if you just want to hack and slash or jump into the campaign mode each week for some RPG lite elements is good so its overall got a good selection of gameplay.

New content is being added all the time and is usually pretty well polished when it comes out but I am still waiting on a DX12 update which has been coming soon since launch.

10/10

Even buying the battle-pass extra rewards there isn't enough Gold generated to buy anything else. This a big problem, I have all ready spent 60 dollars on the game and I am not going to spend on a game that lags, freezes, and crashes when I play it. I have filled out multiple surveys for the game. I hope the game will have a way to earn Gold, I also hope the game becomes less laggy. if your wondering my PC does meet the requirements to run the game well. The game is well made and a lot of work has gone into it. PLEASE FIX THIS PROBLEMS!!!!

Edit: Game has a great core concept and stands out from any other Battle Royale I have played. That being said there are some core issues that need to be addressed with both connections and game-play before I can honestly recommend the game.

There is no ping restriction to the servers so anyone can connect to whatever server they want. This poses an issue in a game with tight controls and parry timing when up against an opponent on the other side of the world (literally).

Additionally the weapons and characters seem to be very unbalanced. There are some weapons that are completely worthless compared to others regardless of whether they fit your play style or not. 

The ranking system has some serious issues that could be addressed with some transparency on how the scoring works. Why when I get 15 kills and do 20K damage in top 3 am I only rewarded 11 points, but in a loss where i'm still within top 10 and have only 4 kills do i LOSE 7 points. Its frustrating and makes any progress towards a ranking system feel hopeless.

Aesthetically the game is fantastic. All the characters sound, look, and feel unique. The environment is great (spare the few times your character will be stuck from some free running glitch)

The main issue is that this game is being pushed so hard as the next big e-sport without having the dedicated team to balance and regulate content it would need for that legitimacy.

TLDR: Amazing Concept, Poor Execution. Your average Tencent style buy skin schlock

The game wants you to disable HVCI_KMCI.
The kernel is basically the ‚Äúcore‚Äù of your computer‚Äôs operating system, having total control over all programs. This means any software that operates at the ‚Äúkernel level‚Äù can easily make changes to your system without you even noticing.

When HVCI KMCI is turned on, essential Windows processes are isolated so they aren‚Äôt prone to tampering. When you turn it off, they are no longer isolated; unsafe but run faster too. This means, when HVCI KMCI is disabled, Naraka Bladepoint‚Äòs anti-cheat can read your files and catch unauthorized commands much more efficiently.

Turning off HVCI KMCI also does give you up to a 12% performance boost when gaming! But it all depends on what games you‚Äôre playing since they all utilize the Windows processes differently. You might think, ‚ÄúThen, just turn it back on when I‚Äôm done gaming,‚Äù right? Well, toggling the setting requires a reboot so it might provide another level of inconvenience.

Still, at the end of the day, it‚Äôs all up to you whether you‚Äôre comfortable with turning off a security feature or not.
